titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the 1964 Mississippi Summer Project Oral Histories, 1994 RL.11814

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-07-02 10:36:35 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

origination.label: source
origination.persname: Farmer, James, 1920-1999. (Title of work: James Farmer, civil rights leader.)

did.abstract: Thirty-four audio WAV files made from source digital audio tapes of interviews, primarily with participants in the Mississippi Freedom Project, from volunteers to organization leaders.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Interviews are arranged alphabetically by interviewee or title of program.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Mississippi Freedom Project, also referred to as the Mississippi Summer Project or Freedom Summer, was organized in 1964 by the Council of Federated Organizations, whose member organizations included the Congress of Racial Equality (CORE), the Student Non-violent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), the National Assocation for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC). The Project had as a central strategy the recruitment of white college students, many from the North, to help register African American voters in the South while drawing attention of the larger United States to voter suppression based on racial discrimination. The murders of Project volunteers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman, and Michael Schwerner in Mississippi in June galvanized the efforts of Freedom Summer volunteers, whose work helped lead to the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The 1964 Mississippi Summer Project oral histories were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2020.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], 1964 Mississippi Summer Project Oral Histories, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2020-0012

p.extref: Center for Documentary Studies, SNCC Legacy Project Critical Oral Histories Conference Interviews, 2016-2018

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Thirty-four audio WAV files made from source digital audio tapes of interviews, primarily with participants in the Mississippi Freedom Project, from volunteers to organization leaders. The recordings were used for a Minnesota Public Radio documentary entitled "O Freedom Over Me," produced by John Biewen and Kate Cavett in 1994. In addition to interviews documenting the Project, Biewen and Cavett also talked to community leaders, educators, and activists regarding conditions for African Americans in Mississippi thirty years after Freedom Summer.

controlaccess.subject: Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (U.S.)
Mississippi Freedom Project
Council of Federated Organizations (U.S.)
Congress of Racial Equality
Documentary radio programs
controlaccess.persname: Farmer, James, 1920-1999. (Title of work: James Farmer, civil rights leader.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In producing their radio documentary in 1994, John Biewen and Kate Cavett used digital audio tape cassettes (DAT), then the cutting edge of portable digital technology. The files in the collection each represent the entirety of a single DAT, and as DAT facilitated high quality and long recording times, many of the files contain more than one interview, along with recordings of ambient sound captured for the production. Interview entries with start and end times provided indicate the interview falls within those times, and that the file includes other interviews or content (listed elsewhere). Those entries with a single time indicate the entire file contains one interview or program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an interview with Bobby Rushing, principal of Indianola Middle School, Indianola, Mississippi, regarding the Algebra Project, a math education program developed by Bob Moses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 00:00:00 to 00:59:00; Hank Allen and Mary Allen, son and daughter of Louis Allen, a black man murdered in 1964 in Liberty, Mississippi for threatening to testify as a witness to the murder of Herbert Lee by state legislator Eugene Hurst.
